Key Arguments: The proposed laws would create an unelected body to decide what is truth, which is seen as dangerous and totalitarian.
There is skepticism about who decides what misinformation is and the potential biases involved.
The legislation is viewed as a threat to free speech and a power grab by elites.
The submission argues for open dialogue and freedom of information as the means to counter misinformation.
Main Themes: Concerns about totalitarianism and loss of democracy
Skepticism about the ability to objectively define truth and misinformation
Notable Quotes: "The party told you to reject the evidence of your eyes and ears. It was their final, most essential command." - George Orwell, 1984
"This MUST NOT STAND. We, the people, have the right to use our own brains, our own processes of deduction and to make our own decisions about what our opinions are."
"If you want to counter misinformation you do this by allowing open dialogue with freedom of information and a robust discussion, not by creating a 'ministry of truth'."
